column1: How do you form the Swedish future with ska?
column2:
Use ska followed by the infinitive.
Vi ska gå på bio på fredag.

column1: Translate to Swedish: We will travel tomorrow.
Translate to Swedish: She will study this evening.
Translate to Swedish: They will cook dinner on Sunday.
column2: De ska laga middag på söndag.

column1: Where do sentence adverbs like aldrig/sällan/ofta/alltid/inte go in a Swedish main clause?
column2:
After the finite verb (V2); after an auxiliary (har, ska, kan, vill, måste, etc.) and before the main verb; rarely in first position.
På kvällen går jag ofta på bio.

column1: Where can the time adverbial 'ibland' be placed?
column2:
Typically in clause-initial or clause-final position.
Ibland går jag på bio. / Jag går på bio ibland.

column1: Translate to Swedish: I never go to the cinema.
Translate to Swedish: We often cook at home.
Translate to Swedish: Sometimes I study at the library.
Translate to Swedish: I go to the cinema sometimes.
When you like a thing (a noun), what pattern do you use?
When you like doing something, what pattern do you use?
column4:
"älskar" + "att" + infinitive
Jag tycker om att lyssna på musik."

column1: What is the difference between tycka" and "tycka om"?"
column2:
tycka" = to think (often with an "att"-clause); "tycka om" = to like
Jag tycker om glass."

column1: Translate to Swedish: I like music.
Translate to Swedish: She loves to cook.
Translate to Swedish: We like listening to music.
column2: Vi tycker om att lyssna på musik.

column1: Translate to Swedish: Do you like sushi?
What does 'på måndag' mean and when do you use it?
column2:
It refers to the coming Monday (future plan/appointment).
På måndag ska jag träffa Ullis.

column1: What does 'på måndagar' mean and when do you use it?
column2:
It means on Mondays (every Monday; a habitual action).
På måndagar brukar jag plugga.

column1: Translate to Swedish: We will meet on Monday.
Translate to Swedish: On Mondays I usually study.
Translate to Swedish: She goes to the gym on Mondays.
column2: Hon går till gymmet på måndagar.

column1: How many grammatical genders does Swedish have, and what are they?
column2:
Two: utrum" (en-words) and "neutrum" (ett-words).
en bok; ett hus"

column1: Which articles/pronouns match each gender?
column2:
Utrum uses en"/"den"; neutrum uses "ett"/"det".
den boken; det huset"

column1: What endings do Swedish adjectives take with en"-words
column4:
Base form with en"; add "-t" with "ett"; add "-a" in plural.
en romantisk film; ett roligt program; läskiga filmer"

column1: How do you form the neuter when an adjective ends in a vowel?
What happens to an adjective that already ends in -t" in the neuter?"
column2:
After a consonant cluster it stays the same; after a long vowel the -t" doubles.
svart → svart; vit → vitt"

column1: How does a final -d" change in the neuter?"
column2:
It becomes -t" (often "-tt" after a long vowel).
hård → hårt; god → gott"

column1: What spelling change happens with adjectives ending in -er" or "-el"?"
column2:
drop the e" before "-a" (plural/definite).
vacker → vackra; enkel → enkla"

column1: Which adjectives keep the same form in all genders and numbers?
column2:
Those ending in -ande" and invariable adjectives like "bra".
fascinerande; bra"

column1: What are the neuter and plural forms of liten"?"
Translate to Swedish: a new house.
Translate to Swedish: two black cars.
Translate to Swedish: a hard test.
Translate to Swedish: a white table.
How do you form Swedish 'preteritum' for group 1 verbs (imperative ends in '-a')?
How do you form 'preteritum' for group 2a verbs (imperative ends in a voiced consonant)?
How do you form 'preteritum' for group 2b verbs (imperative ends in 'k, p, s, t, x')?
How do you form 'preteritum' for group 3 verbs (imperative ends in a long vowel)?
What characterises group 4 verbs in 'preteritum'?
column2:
They are irregular (strong) and must be memorised.
skriv → skrev; vara → var

column1: Preteritum: Group 2a – If the imperative ends in which consonants do you add -de?
column2:
a voiced consonant (e.g., b, d, g, v, m, n, r, l)
ring → ringde; kör → körde

column1: Preteritum: Group 2b – If the imperative ends in which consonants do you add -te?
column2:
k, p, s, t, x
köp → köpte; läs → läste

column1: Translate to Swedish: I worked yesterday.
Translate to Swedish: We bought a car.
Translate to Swedish: He lived in Uppsala.
Translate to Swedish: They wrote a letter.
What does the Swedish relative pronoun 'som' do?
column2:
It links two sentences and refers back to a noun; no gender/number change.
Jag har en kusin som är skådespelare.

column1: What is the word order inside a 'som'-clause?
column2:
Subclause order: if 'som' is subject, verb follows; if 'som' is object, the subject comes before the verb.
en vän som bor i Malmö (som = subjekt)
boken som jag läser (som = objekt)

column1: Translate to Swedish: I have a cousin who is an actor.
column2: Jag har en kusin som är (en) skådespelare.

column1: Translate to Swedish: We have a neighbor who works at the hospital.
column2: Vi har en granne som arbetar på sjukhuset.

column1: Translate to Swedish: This is the book that I am reading.
column2: Det här är boken som jag läser.

column1: Translate to Swedish: She likes dogs that are small.
column2: Hon tycker om hundar som är små.

column1: Possessive pronouns: What are the forms of 'my' and how do they agree?
column2:
They agree with the possessed noun: 'en' → 'min', 'ett' → 'mitt', 'plural' → 'mina'.
Min syster bor i Tyskland.

column1: Possessive pronouns: How do plural owners 'our'/'your (pl.)' agree with the noun?
column2:
Use 'vår'/'vårt'/'våra' and 'er'/'ert'/'era'; the form follows the noun’s gender/number.
Vårt hus är gammalt.

column1: Possessive pronouns: Which third-person possessives are invariable?
column2:
'hans', 'hennes', 'hens'; for things/unknown gender: 'dess'; plural owners: 'deras'.
Hans bok ligger här.

column1: Possessive pronouns: Who decides the stem and who decides the ending (–/–t/–a)?
column2:
The owner decides the stem ('min'/'din'/'vår'/'er'); the following noun decides the ending (–/–t/–a).
Vi köper vår cykel, målar vårt hus och besöker våra vänner.

column1: Possessive pronouns: What happens to definiteness after a possessive?
column2:
The noun is normally indefinite (no '-en'/'-et'/'-na' ending).
Min bok ligger här.

column1: Possessive pronouns: When do you use the gender-neutral 'hens'?
column2:
Use 'hens' when the person is referred to as 'hen' (gender-neutral singular).
Kim tog hens jacka.

column1: How do you say “its” in Swedish?
column2:
Use 'dess' for things or unknown gender.
Cykeln och dess färg är nya.

column1: Translate to Swedish: My sister lives in Germany.
Translate to Swedish: My grandchild is called Noah.
Translate to Swedish: My brothers live in Canada.
Translate to Swedish: Is this your car?
Translate to Swedish: Is this your house?
Translate to Swedish: Are these your keys?
Translate to Swedish: Our apartment is small.
Translate to Swedish: Our children are tired.
Translate to Swedish: His book is on the table.
Translate to Swedish: Her idea was good.
Translate to Swedish: Their dog is friendly.
Translate to Swedish: The bicycle and its color are new.
column2: Cykeln och dess färg är nya.

column1: Translate to Swedish: Anna likes her own car.
Translate to Swedish: My new car is fast.
Object pronouns: What is the object form of 'jag'?
column2:
The object form of 'jag' is 'mig'.
Mamma ringer mig.

column1: Object pronouns: What is the object form of 'du'?
column2:
The object form of 'du' is 'dig'.
Jag ringer dig i morgon.

column1: Object pronouns: What is the object form of 'han'?
column2:
The object form of 'han' is 'honom'.
Hon såg honom i går.

column1: Object pronouns: What is the object form of 'hon'?
column2:
The object form of 'hon' is 'henne'.
Jag chattar med henne varje dag.

column1: Object pronouns: What is the object form of 'hen'?
column2:
The object form of 'hen' is 'hen'.
Jag träffade hen.

column1: Object pronouns: What is the object form of 'den'?
column2:
The object form of 'den' is 'den'.
Var är cykeln? Jag ser den.

column1: Object pronouns: What is the object form of 'det'?
column2:
The object form of 'det' is 'det'.
Här är glaset; jag ställer det här.

column1: Object pronouns: What is the object form of 'vi'?
column2:
The object form of 'vi' is 'oss'.
De ringer oss nu.

column1: Object pronouns: What is the object form of 'ni'?
column2:
The object form of 'ni' is 'er'.
Jag hör er tydligt.

column1: Object pronouns: What is the object form of 'de'?
column2:
The object form of 'de' is 'dem'.
Vi träffar dem i kväll.

column1: Object pronouns: When do you use 'den' vs 'det' for things?
column2:
Use 'den' with 'en'-words and 'det' with 'ett'-words.
Var är cykeln? Jag ser den.

column1: Object pronouns: Do they follow prepositions?
column2:
Yes—object pronouns are used after prepositions.
Jag chattar med henne.

column1: Object pronouns: Where do they usually appear in a main clause?
column2:
After the finite verb.
Jag ringer dig i morgon.

column1: Object pronouns: How do you write and say plural 'them'?
column2:
Write 'dem'; it’s commonly pronounced 'dom'.
Vi träffar dem i kväll.

column1: Object pronouns: Do object forms take endings?
column2:
No—object forms don’t inflect beyond subject vs object.
Hon älskar mig.

column1: Translate to Swedish: Mom calls me every day.
Translate to Swedish: I’ll call you tomorrow.
Translate to Swedish: We will say hello to him.
Translate to Swedish: I chat with her every day.
column2: Jag chattar med henne varje dag.

column1: Translate to Swedish: I eat dinner with them every Sunday.
column2: Jag äter middag med dem varje söndag.

column1: Translate to Swedish: I am happy with it.
Translate to Swedish: Where is the bicycle? I see it.
column2: Var är cykeln? Jag ser den.

column1: Translate to Swedish: Here is the glass; I’ll put it here.
column2: Här är glaset; jag ställer det här.

column1: Translate to Swedish: We meet them tonight.
Translate to Swedish: She saw him yesterday.
Translate to Swedish: Do you know her?
Translate to Swedish: Talk to me!
Translate to Swedish: They are calling us now.
Translate to Swedish: He is angry with it.
Translate to Swedish: I love you.
Translate to Swedish: The cat likes us.
Translate to Swedish: Are you talking to them?
Verb groups: How are groups identified?
Verb groups: What are the 'presens' endings by group?
Verb groups: What defines group '1'?
Verb groups: What defines group '2a'?
column2:
Imperative stem ends in a voiced consonant; 'presens' is '-er'. Some verbs have identical imperative and 'presens'.
ring! → ringer

column1: Verb groups: Which consonants are voiced for group '2a'?
column2:
'b, d, g, v, m, n, r, l, j, ng'.
kör! → kör

column1: Verb groups: What defines group '2b'?
column2:
Imperative stem ends in a voiceless consonant; 'presens' is '-er'.
köp! → köper

column1: Verb groups: Which consonants are voiceless for group '2b'?
Verb groups: What defines group '3'?
column2:
Infinitive/imperative end in a long vowel (not '-a'); 'presens' is '-r'.
bo! → bor

column1: Verb groups: What defines group '4'?
column2:
Strong/irregular verbs with stem changes; learn forms individually.
skriva → skriver

column1: Translate to Swedish: Speak slowly!
Translate to Swedish: Build a house!
Translate to Swedish: Read the text!
Translate to Swedish: We buy bread.
Translate to Swedish: He lives in Malmö.
Translate to Swedish: They write every day.
Translate to Swedish: We are going now.
Translate to Swedish: Do you hear me?
Translate to Swedish: Drive carefully!
Då-adverb + preteritum: What is a 'då-adverb' and which tense follows?
column2:
A time adverb naming a specific past time; the verb is in 'preteritum'.
Jag var på fest i måndags.

column1: Då-adverb + preteritum: Where does the verb go if the clause begins with a 'då-adverb'?
column2:
In position 2 ('V2').
I höstas hörde vi om Nobelpriset.

column1: Då-adverb + preteritum: How many 'då-adverb' can a clause contain?
column2:
Only one—use the most specific time.
I måndags åt jag lunch.

column1: Då-adverb + preteritum: How are weekday forms built?
Då-adverb + preteritum: What are the season forms?
column2:
'i våras', 'i somras', 'i höstas', 'i vintras'.
I somras reste vi mycket.

column1: Då-adverb + preteritum: What are the holiday forms?
column2:
'i julas', 'i påskas', 'i midsomras'.
I julas var jag hemma.

column1: Translate to Swedish: last spring.
Translate to Swedish: last summer.
Translate to Swedish: last autumn.
Translate to Swedish: last winter.
Translate to Swedish: last Christmas.
Translate to Swedish: last Easter.
Translate to Swedish: last Midsummer.
Translate to Swedish: Last Monday I was at city hall.
column2: I måndags var jag i stadshuset.

column1: Translate to Swedish: Last Friday I saw the film.
Pronouns: någon & ingen — When do you use 'någon'/'något'/'några'?
column2:
Use them for an unspecified person/thing/quantity (before a noun or alone).
Känner du någon här?

column1: Pronouns: någon & ingen — How do 'ingen/inget/inga' relate to 'inte' + 'någon/något/några'?
column2:
They are equivalent negatives; choose either pattern.
Jag har ingen bil = Jag har inte någon bil.

column1: Pronouns: någon & ingen — What forms match 'en/ett/plural'?
Pronouns: någon & ingen — What happens in a two-verb clause?
column2:
Use 'inte' + 'någon/något/några' (avoid 'ingen/inget/inga').
Jag vill inte ha någon ketchup.

column1: Pronouns: någon & ingen — Are double negations allowed?
column2:
No; do not use 'inte' + 'ingen/inget/inga'.
Jag har ingen bil.

column1: Pronouns: någon & ingen — What can 'några' mean?
column2:
“A few,” often about 2–3 items.
Jag köpte några böcker.

column1: Translate to Swedish: Do you have a bike? (any bike)
Translate to Swedish: Do we have any fruit at home?
Translate to Swedish: Yes, we have a few oranges.
Translate to Swedish: I have no car.
Translate to Swedish: We don’t have any apples.
Translate to Swedish: I don’t want any ketchup.
column2: Jag vill inte ha någon ketchup.

column1: Translate to Swedish: She doesn’t have any money.
Translate to Swedish: Do you know anyone here?
Translate to Swedish: I would like some detective novel.
column2: Jag vill gärna ha någon deckare.

column1: Translate to Swedish: He doesn’t have any questions.
What ending turns the indefinite plural of Groups 1–4 and 6b into the definite plural?
What ending makes the definite plural of Group 5 nouns such as “täcke”?
What ending is added to form the definite plural of Group 6a nouns like “lakan”?
Translate to Swedish: The lamps are on the table.
Translate to Swedish: The blankets are heavy.
Translate to Swedish: The sheets are clean.
What endings create the comparative and superlative of regular Swedish adjectives?
Translate to Swedish: Do you have anything cheaper?
Translate to Swedish: They are the nicest.
Translate to Swedish: This jacket is nicer.
column2:
Den här jackan är finare.
fin → finare

column1: Which preposition follows comparative adjectives in Swedish?
When do you use the superlative instead of the comparative?
column2:
When comparing all members of a group or both items as a whole.
Stockholm är störst av de två

column1: How do you compare adjectives ending in -ande, -ad or -isk in the comparative and superlative?
column2:
With mer (comparative) and mest (superlative).
serien är mest spännande

column1: How do you translate worse"/"the worst" when you describe something that is always bad?"
column2:
värre / värst
Min migrän är värre i dag

column1: Translate to Swedish: The shirt is cheaper than the sweater.
column2:
Skjortan är billigare än tröjan.
billigare än

column1: Translate to Swedish: Stockholm is the biggest of the two cities.
column2:
Stockholm är störst av de två städerna.
störst av de två

column1: Translate to Swedish: The weather is worse today.
Translate to Swedish: She is more interested in series than film.
column2:
Hon är mer intresserad av serier än film.
mer ... än

column1: How do you form the Swedish present perfect (presens perfekt)?
How is the supinum formed in verb groups 1 and 2?
How is the supinum formed in verb group 3?
What is the supinum ending for IT-verbs in group 4a like “skriv”?
Translate to Swedish: I have spoken Swedish today.
Translate to Swedish: She has called her mother.
Translate to Swedish: We have lived here for two years.
column2: Vi har bott här i två år.

column1: Translate to Swedish: They have written a letter.
